content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Thought it was gonna be exactly like Dead Island, ended up being an improvement imo.It's not perfect so if you wanna see what I have bad to say about the game, skip to the cons.It's a great experience if you actually get into it, if you like killing zombies and parkouring, you should feel right at home, in this new enviroment. So here's a serious review.Before I start, alot of people with AMD cards report bad fps, so be aware of that.Actually check the system requirements before purchasing, so you don't end up complaining about hardware problems.- Pros/Features- +Decent story, there are still ridiculous and bizarre side quests. There are some really colorful characters in this game. But honestly, if you have a sense of humor you'll get a good laugh out of some parts of the storyline.+Parkour, allows you to navigate the enviroment in a very different way, viral zombies can parkour as well and are pretty decent at it.+Survival senses (Spider senses?) If you press the Q button, your survival senses kick in and will basically show little markings on lootable objects/items that you can pick up or interact with. Some people may find this a turn off, but honestly, there is ALOT of looting in this game, when your running from zombies, or low on time, it's helpful. It also shows the waypoint, so it's easy to figure out where your supposed to go without checking the map constantly. Overall it's a nice feature, and extremely helpful.+Crafting is very simple, create shurikens, medkits, molotovs, even beneficial boosters which are created with herbs. (Such as improved night vision, or damage resistance) As well as blueprints which let you modify weapons you already have, and add pretty devasating effects. Very similar to dead Island with the blueprints, except there are alot more. Some even let you put multiple elemental effects on a single weapon. +Weapon mechanics work well. Different weapons have different amounts of upgrade slots. You can add things like "Crusader" or "Juggernaut" to your weapon to increase handling/durability etc. on top of this you can upgrade with blueprints you find such as fire, electricity, and toxic. similar to Dead Island, but a step up with the new upgrades. You can also repair your weapons using tool parts that you loot. Eventually the weapon will break, but it's nice that you can repair and delay the inevitible.You can also dismantle weapons which gives you 1 or a couple repair parts.+Control over the combat. With the skill tree upgrades you can unlock the ability to dodge, unlock new weapon moves. Grapple opponets, dropkick them. You can also kick zombies/humans into spikes in the enviroment, and even use traps found in the open world such as electric fences, car bombs, and more.+The player can also hold up to 4 different equipments at a time (Shurikens, grenades, molotovs, UV light, etc.)+3 different skill trees, level up independently (Agility, Power, and Survival.) Everytime you level one of these up you can pick a skill which gives access to new crafting items, unlocks new moves such as the dropkick, or increases speed and whatknot. There's quite alot of upgrades.Power is increased by fighting enemies, you unlock combat moves for weapons among other things.Agility is increased by doing parkour, jumping, etc. Unlocks moves like the dropkick, also increases stats.And survival is increased by doing quests and recovering airdrop packages. These give alot of upgrades like making crafting more effective, learning new crafts, and also unlocking moves. When you die you also lose survival points, which makes it more intense.Overall the skill system is really good in my opinion, they can each go up to level 25. +Looting feels good, honestly I think they nailed the RPG feeling of just getting tons of loot.You can go in alot of the buildings, picklock chests. Most of these buildings have locked doors, so you have to look around and find different entrances such as going through a roof door, or lifting up the garage door.The human enemies will drop melee weapons, if their using them, as well as throwing items.And even the special zombies have some weapons you can pick up which include the concrete rebars and sledgehammer.+Special zombies are actually pretty interesting. It basically has the suicider from Dead Island still, but their are spitters which lob poisonous exploding bile (extremely annoying) And concrete rebar wielding zombies which are like 3 times the size of a normal zombie. Even the hazmat zombies are cool, they sound grim, and explode on death. Night zombies, are brutal...and yeah I stay away from them.(Very much a stepup from Dead Island with some of these zombie variants imo.)+Guns are a HUGE improvement from Dead Island. They handle better, and actually kill the targets instead of them just soaking up bullets. Exception to this is some of the special zombies, which depending on the type can take alot more bullets.The guns are somewhat overpowered because of the availability of ammunition, but they cause major noise which usually attracts alot of zombies. +Human combat is intense, most of the enemies wield different weapons, can throw knives, and will dodge accordingly, they can even block items such as throwing knives unless you time them correctly. The gunplay here is also improved, they die quite easily from bullets, but if they are wielding guns they can kill the player just as quickly if given the opportunity. This is my experience with the game, I came into it expecting a mediocre game and ended up getting an awesome open world experience. If you like killing zombies, parkouring, crafting, making awesome weapons, exploring an open world, just buy the game and play it. Develop your own opinion. - Cons - -Experienced quite a few crashes throughout my gameplay. A couple during cutscenes, and alot over the course of just traveling/doing missions. Nothing game breaking though, thankfully the autosave works out. Still, it's annoying having to reboot the game.-No manual save (This is a big deal to me) I really hate when games leave you with an autosave feature and no manual save. Haven't had any huge problems with it yet, but it would be nice to be able to manually save.-Some people report AMD card problems.- No vehicles, but parkour is more fun in my opinion, didn't really have a problem with no vehicles.-"Resize buffer failed" Not sure what this means, but this has crashed my game about 5 times over 13 hours. Thankfully the game autosaves, and I haven't lost any of my loot to it yet. Still it's extremely annoying and needs to be fixed.-Most of the time when I load my save my character says "OH♥♥♥♥♥♥" I don't really consider this a con, but it's pretty entertaining. I can't think of any, i've been playing for quite a while and haven't run across any game breaking bugs. I'll add more cons if I do find some though.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Definitely worth buying.  Since there is no demo, SWIM torrented the game to check performance.  Given the trend of bad ports running poorly on high end hardware regardless of system requirements, it's really the only way to protect yourself from $60 of regret that will eat at you forever.So anyways... to the game!  It's a zombie survival FPS game which is all the craze these days, but they did manage to bring something new to the table.  It doesn't feel like anything else out there.  Some games give you an arsenal and promote shooting your way through zombies, other games don't give you any weapons but make you wander around defenseless in the dark, and Dying Light does neither of these.  Guns are rare so using your enviornment and blunt force weapons are how you'll kill zombies.  But most of the time it's better to evade, which you do using the new parkour system.  Parkour and manuverabiltiy are a huge part of the game, and they pulled it off surprisingly well.  I expected it to be buggy and have its shortcomings, but it seems to work perfect.The story is intreguing, missions varied so it doesn't feel like you're doing the same thing over and over, and it feels like a fresh title instead of a rehash of someone else's idea.As far as performance goes, it runs great on my i7 4770k 3.5GHz/SLI 780 setup.  I have most of the settings maxed out except for Shadows and Draw Distance (which is set to half way), and I get 60-80fps outdoors and 144+ indoors running at 1080p.Your CPU has a major effect on the performance in this game, as it mainly uses just a single core.  So if you're running a modern Intel setup you're going to have a better time than someone who has more but slower cores (like with most AMD rigs).I tend to buy games, give them a 10 or 20 minute chance to grab my interest... and usually never open them again.  But Dying Light breaks the mold and has me hooked.

												Pros:Open-World2 Maps (Slums/Oldtown)Loads of fun on multiplayerWeapon Mods2 different play-styles depending on the time in-game (Day/Night)Different types of infected (Normal, Virals, Bombers, Volatiles, Spitters and more)Lots of different weaponsReally good Parkour (Not glitchy)3 skill trees to level and get new abilities Crafting (bombs,throwing knifes and much more)Side-questsCons:"Be the Zombie" mode is pointless (Everyone you try to play with just quits)Not a lot of dialogue/voices (All shops just say the same stuff, etc.)Most of the zombies look the same with different colour clothesSome bad animations in coopI would rate the game 8/10 because it is a lot of fun to play on your own, but it is even more fun if your playing with other people, it has alot of things to do and the whole game can be played in coop and it also has 45 side-quests to do after the story which is quite a lot as they aren't to short.**I haven't put the story in Pros or Cons because some people think its good and others bad.**

												When I got Dead Island, I was disapointed because for me,the game felt doll and boring (I'm more the single player type) so when I saw dying Light, I wanted to give Techland another chance so I waited for a good sale (got the game for 20$) and right at the start of it I fell in love with it.Story: The story was decent, sure I didn't expected that it would be like Mass Effect but it was fun to play.Gameplay: This is the real star of the game, I felt like playing Mirror's Edge in a zombie open world, the game play was fast,fun and balaced (while the end game got my nurves lol). I only wish that while free roaming there was a more tracks.Overall,I can recommend Dying Light to any one who os looking for a fun game that will last for a while, is it worth 60$? Well I don't know but with the new DLC I think it is because of Techland's support and the community, there will be always new things to do in the game.

												Dying light is a very great game that I truly enjoy. For starters the main story line is not extremely long to a point where the player is confused and it's not too short to where the player would become bored or finish it fast. All in all I truly love this game and if you are able to run this game and you like open world zombie killing games ((or a fan of Dead Island)) then Dying light is a game you should get.Good Night and Good Luck

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
For those of you who don't want to read a proper review, here's a summary:- I found extremely few bugs.- The game runs smoothly enough. FPS dips from 75 down to 45 occurs from time to time.- The game is TRULY frightening at night.- If you do as many of the side missions as you can, you'll get great gameplay value for your buck.- I gave this game a 10/10.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -First off, a thank you to Techland.I'm a gamer who never falls for the trailer hype. Ever. Why? Because they're made to sell the game. Wait! Before you say "well duh, of course it's made to sell the game", just let me explain... Even the worst game ever made can have a badass trailer. It doesn't matter how big of a turd a game is, it can still look like the shiniest diamond with the help of a good trailer.This is why I decided that before I bought this game I should probably check out some game play footage. This is where I throw out a HUGE thank you to Techland/WB for deciding to give select Youtubers exclusive access to this game before release. It really payed off for me, and probably for Techland as well.On to the review!I loved Dead Island and Dead Island Riptide (again, because I didn't fall for the trailer hype), and one of my favorite games of all time is Mirror's Edge. Therefore this game fits me like a glove. It has the braindead slaughter of zombies plus awesome free-running all wrapped up in a stunningly beautiful package.Sufficed to say, this is a pretty solid game. However, not without its flaws and optimization was one of very few. My FPS dips to 45 at certain points, but most of the time it's a solid 75-ish. Good thing I'm not an obsessed performance freak, or I would've found that annoying and ripped this game a new a-hole just based on that. Yeah... I'm looking at you, fools. You know who you are.Anyway...I think Techland did the right thing when they decided to make this game (which was obviously meant to be Dead Island 2) and dump the semi-bad reputation of Dead Island in someone else's lap. It has the exact same mechanics of Dead Island and it plays exactly like a Dead Island game. Now this is not something bad. On the contrary. Techland learned from their mistakes with Dead Island - and obviously wanted to start over with a fresh franchise and thus a better reputation - and they managed to fix everything that was wrong with the Dead Island games.I only experienced two bugs in the first 30 hours of playing the game; one where a zombie clipped through the hood of a car (happened 3 times) and me falling through the world when climbing a com tower (happened once and never again). That is not bad at all by any video game standard.The crafting system is exactly the same as in Dead Island with one exception: you can't upgrade guns. This is neither a good nor bad thing. They are guns. Shoot a zombie in the head and it'll die wether you do 500 extra electrocute damage to it or not. Gun modifications could have been helpful when trying to take down some of the bigger brutes in the game, but it's not a big deal since you can avoid 99.9% of them anyway. Dying Light is not a gun-heavy game and you will not miss these upgrades.I have one main rule when it comes to buying games; get roughly 1 hour of gameplay per euro payed. If you are like me you will not be disappointed. Granted I did get my game cheaper than on Steam at another retailer, so I was quite happy since it has already pretty much payed off, with me having played just about 50% of the main story in almost 31 hours.And no in-game shop for micro-transactions! Thank you!I've been thinking hard about the negative aspects of this game and I can't really think of anything. I haven't experienced anything bad or game breaking at all. The climbing is solid as a rock - no Assassin's Creed BS where your character jumps opposite of where you wanted him to go half the time - and the game's mechanics work well. The skill trees are helpful and actually do make the game a tiny bit easier for you, but not so easy as to you just running through the game without even trying. It really feels as if Crane has become more skilled at what he does and it's the perfect feeling for a game like this. The skills do exactly what they should. You are not a god, you are just a man who, as time goes by, learns how to take care of himself in a zombie infested world.And of course, night missions are scary as hell. +1!This game gets a solid 10 out of 10 from me. It's a breath of fresh air in an otherwise over-saturated market filled to the brim with rehashes, micro-transactions and badly optimized games with huge day one patches. Thank you, Techland. You did extremely well.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
Recensione Italiana in fondo---Welcome to Dead Island 2 Dying Light. For the one who already know Dead Island's saga: Dying Light is heavily, really a lot, based on DI's mechanics, you will still find a distant tropical city with an unknown infection, a huge load of loot and weapons that can be upgraded with projects, all of this while you level up your character in 3 different skill trees. Plus you will have parkour style movements that will allow you to jump over obstacles, climbs on various surfaces, run over cables between roofs and many other things, including a grappling hook later in the game.For the one that don't know the Dead Island's saga: Add to what we said above that the game is an open world first person shooter where the weapon you will usually use are melee weapons, not guns, and you will have a questlog system to keep track on what missions you have and what to follow. The main focus of the game is that you will find various components during the game (iron pieces, gauze, electric cables,...) by looting item and corpses and with those things you will be able to upgrade your weapons with projects you will learn around. Plus the various actions you will perform (doing missions, do parkour, fighting, ...) will give you experience points in 3 different branch (Survival, Agility e Combat) that work like 3 independent skill-tree that will grand abilities to your character making him stronger.Dying Light has a slighty more serious feel compared to his two predecessor(the 2 Dead Island) with more aggresive and resistant zombies that will force you at the low levels to stay on the roofs, plus the Night that not only will increase the zombies stats but will spwan the Nocturnal, ferocius zombies that will be your nightmare at least until halfway the game. The story looks like to be trying to follow a more mature and emotional path but in my opinion they did not meet the wanted results, it's clique and not engaging with predictable plot twists. Even your big nemesis that I think was born like an evil, slightly mad but charismatic character is a collage of boring catchphrases and "already heard" speeches.The good side is that this is a big game with two ample maps (Slums and Old Town) where you can't fast travel (except from map to map) and with various random events that vary with the story. Even the secondary missions are many (more than 50 if you count every mission that lands in your questlog) and the main story count a quite good amount of missions as well. To complete it with almost all the secondaty missions done (except the single players one, see below) it took me 45 hours in coop.Pro:  Many missions, many hours of gameplay Stunning graphics Really beautiful to play with friends Thousands of moddable weapons Parkour movements system is well done and funnyCons:  Story lack of originality As well as the npc characters, clique and don't develop At high levels the fear for the night and the zombies hordes goes away, you are Terminator If you want high graphics you will need a really good computer Single player mode only for the protection missions, a weird choice for a coop oriented game. Even more if you think that they were coop in Dead Island Weird choice as well to make the FINAL mission single player only It remembers WAY TOO MUCH Dead Island (excluded parkour), they should have tried something more---Benvenuti in Dead Island 2 Dying Light. Per quelli che già conoscono la saga di Dead Island: Dying Light è fortemente, molto fortemente, basato sulle meccaniche di DI, troverete ancora una remota città tropicale con una infezione misteriosa, loot a non finire con svariate armi alle quali applicare progetti mentre sviluppate il vostro personaggio tramite 3 skill set differenti. In più avrete dei movimenti in stile parkour che vi permetteranno di superare ostacoli, correre, scalare edifici, sfruttare corde sospese e più avanti nel gioco anche un rampino.Per quelli che non conoscono la saga di Dead Island: Oltre ciò detto sopra sappiate che il gioco è un first person shooter open world dove le armi che andrete ad usare principalmente sono le armi da mischia, non quelle da fuoco, e avrete un sistema di questlog che vi permetterà di scegliere quale missione seguire in un dato momento. La caratteristica del gioco è il poter trovare componenti vari (pezzi di metallo, garze, componenti elettronici,...) con le quali potrete creare dei potenziamenti per le vostre armi. Inoltre le differenti azioni che farete (completare missioni, fare parkour, combattere, ...) vi daranno punti esperienza in 3 diversi settori (Sopravvivenza, Agilità e Combattimento) che funzionano come skill-tree indipendenti dai quali scegliere varie abilità che renderanno il vostro personaggio migliore.Dying Light è caratterizzato da un'impronta leggermente più seria dei suoi predecessori (I 2 Dead Island) con zombie più cattivi e resistenti che ai livelli bassi vi costringeranno a stare sui tetti e l'avvento della notte che non solo migliorerà la forza dei non morti ma farà anche comparire i tremendi notturni che fino ad almeno metà gioco saranno il vostro incubo. Anche la storia sembra voglia seguire un'impronta più matura ed emozionale anche se a mio avviso non hanno centrato il bersaglio, risulta scontata e poco coinvolgente con colpi di scena facilmente prevedibili. Anche la vostra grande nemesi che penso avessero inteso come una persona malvagia, un po' pazza ma carismatica è un'insieme di frasi "ad effetto" poco originali.Il lato buono però è che si tratta di un gioco molto vasto con due grandi mappe (Bassifondi e Città Vecchia) nella quali non è possibile viaggiare rapidamente (a parte da una maxi mappa all'altra) e con svariati eventi casuali che mutano ad un certo punto del gioco. Anche le missioni secondarie sono svariate (più di 50 se si tiene conto di ogni missione che va nel quest log) e la storia principale si difende bene in termini di numero di missioni. In tutto per completarlo con quasi tutte le missioni secondarie fatte (tranne le singleplayer, vedi poi) ci ho messo 45 ore in coop.Pro:  Tante missioni, tante ore di gioco Grafica mozzafiato Bellissimo da giocare con altre persone Migliaia di armi modificabili Il sistema di movimento a parkour è molto divertente e ben fattoContro:  La storia non brilla certo per originalità Così come i personaggi che incontrerete sono alquanto piatti Ai livelli alti la paura della notte e delle folle di zombie scompare, siete Terminator Requisiti di sistema esosi se volete alzare il livello della grafica Missioni di protezione solo single player, scelta bizzarra in un gioco che punta al coop. Ancora di più considerando che esistevano coop in Dead Island Così come la missione finale è solo single player, scelta strana  Ricorda davvero troppo Dead Island nelle meccaniche (escluso il parkour), avrebbero dovuto osare di più

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												As a massive fan of the original Dead Island I was surprised at my lack of hype of Dying Light which may have something to do with me not clicking with Riptide. After spending 8 hours in Dying Light I can say this should have been Dead Island 2. so far I've only completed 15% of the main story because I keep losing myself in the games sidequests which, after the first 3 hours of painstaking tutorial missions, come thick and fast and each has been interesting enough to make me do them first. Mixing the combat of Dead Island with a parkour mechanic for getting to higher ground faster, Dying Light feels more dynamic in every way, especially during the night missions (night isn't scripted but an actual cycle) when the machanics change stealth style as you face the volatiles, Zombies that can run as fast as you and can take you down in seconds. The visuals are gorgeous at max settings although the best settings come at a very high performance cost so your going to need something beefy to run it at those settings.Dying Light jis easily one the best zombie games available and in my opinion beats my previous favourite; Dead Island.EDIT: 23 hours in and still in the first map. This game has a shedload of interesting content to do away from the main missions.The ollowing Update: Just a small note on the Paid DLC that was released as part of the Enhanced Edition update. This DLC is massive, adding in new quests over a whole new map that is easily as good as the content in the main game. You are given a buggy ala Half Life 2 to upgrade and repair along with new weapons. If you liked the main game then this is unmissable.

PRO - Poveste jocului - Soundtrack-ul - Grafica- Gameplay-ul ( Iti poti crafta armele, sa le upgradezi, sa cauti resurse sa le duci in baza ) - Parkour-ul - Side-quest ( Evident dupa ce ai terminat jocul , poti sa continui faci cele 44 de side-questuri. Aceste side-questuri au legatura cu povestea in sine , deci ar fi bine sa nu faci aceste questuri fix cand terminati jocul ) - Limitarea armelor - Rick Grimes ( sa-ti pui organe de zombie pe tine ca sa nu te urmareasca zombie ) - Challenge ( O sa gasiti tot felul de personaje care va provoaca la diferite concursuri  ) CONTRA- Optimizarea lasa de dorit- Coop-ul la aceast joc lasa de dorit - Modul multiplayer Concluzie Merita sa va jucati acest joc . Aveti o gramada de facut in acest joc , de la misiuni principale la cele secundare plus challenge-uri si alte chestii de explorat . Un lucru important este ca puteti descarca devkit-ul pentru acest joc. Deci cand nu mai aveti ce face in Dying Light puteti sa descarca devkit-ul si puteti sa va faceti propia harta si dupa sa o postati pe workshop. Sau la randul vostru sa descarcati harti facute de comunitate si sa va jucati. Acum astept sa joc acel expansion The Following. Sa speram ca o sa continuie povestea care si asa s-a terminat in copac. Nota finala 8. Si un review la Dying Light The Following Expansion va urma in zilele urmatoare !

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
OverviewAs a fan of all things zombie, I’ve been looking forward to Dying Light for a while now. Overall, it’s a great game, and it has much going for it, but there are some odd design issues, a serious case of couriering (is that a word?) and just some attention-to-detail features that make me go, what?I’ve played for about 28 hours, I’m at 70% story completion, I’ve finished 39 side missions, and I’ve done six of the quarantine zones, as of the time of this review.Want the TL:DR? Great game with great mechanics, a story that slowly devolves into a clichéd mess, with some technical issues that shouldn’t really exist, and a few questionable design choices spread throughout. Still a great game. If I were to put it on a numbered scale, it’d get a seven out of ten.The Good+ Visuals are astounding, great atmospheric effects (such as debris floating around), explosions look terrific, zombies have great models. One touch I quite like is if a viral is in front of you and screams, their mouth actually opens and closes as it screams. Not a big deal, but adds a touch of realism.+ Sound is also great, be it the music or effects. Connecting with a melee weapon gives a satisfying crunch, and guns sound like how guns should; firing off a shotgun blast results in a roar, not a pathetic tinny sound many games use for gun sounds.+ The story, at least at the beginning. Sure, it’s rehashed (something happens, people become zombies), but it’s presented differently and keeps you intrigued for a bit, drawing you into wondering what happened.+ The main mission. The primary goal of the game changes a few hours into the story, but the missions that you undertake for the main story are great, and they aren’t recycled very much.+ Parkour. If Dying Light didn’t have a parkour element, it would definitely be your standard zombie exploration game. Not only does the parkour add an extra dimension, but it’s also done right; it doesn’t feel tacky or sloppy.+ Progression and perks. There are three categories you improve in: Survivor, Agility, Power. Survivor points are gained by completing quests and quarantine zones, as well as challenges. Agility points are gained by just playing the game; climbing, jumping, strafing. Power points are gained by killing; melee, firearms, explosions, traps. There are 25 levels of each, and the perks are pretty nice. They act as a tree, and to unlock one, you’ll have to unlock the first tier and go from there. It’s not too in-depth, but adds a nice touch.+ Night mode. Nighttime adds an extra layer of trouble for you; it’s pitch black, and there are more dangerous zombies with heightened senses. It’s basically a stealth mode. However, completing quests, exploring or just being outside doubles what you earn for the period.+ Random events. There are many random events. Air drops, which contain relief packages and some other goodies, are the big one for the first little bit. Get there quick enough, it’ll be yours. Take your time, you may have to fight off some other humans for it. Take too long, and you’ll lose the drop completely. There will be random survivors under attack who will reward you for helping them. Some people may turn into shopkeepers when you save them, giving you another location to buy and sell from. Some people might only be there to give some background on life in Harran before the outbreak. Maybe you’ll help a group of survivors fight off some zombies, only to have them attack you afterwards. Lots can happen!The Bad- The story. As I said, the story starts off great, but after a couple of hours, it devolves into what has been seen hundreds of times before. I won’t give it away, but you can likely figure out what your goal changes to.- Hit detection/clipping. I’ve mainly seen this on the bigger guys with the huge rebars, but the hit detection is atrocious. He’ll begin swinging, I’ll dodge backwards completely out of range (even of the shockwave), yet I’ll still get hit by it. Same for clipping. I might run behind a truck, yet the attack still manages to get me.- First aid. To make a medkit, you need alcohol and gauze. Pretty realistic, as that will actually tend to wounds, although not restore you fully. Yet every single first aid/medical box you open will have gauze. Just gauze. No alcohol. A few hours in, I had maybe nine bottles of alcohol, yet I was up to 50 or so gauze. Just seems weird.- Night mode. Yes, night mode is good (see The Good). But it’s not really that much more difficult. Your survivor sense will show an outline of the dangerous ones, and the minimap always shows their vision cone, so it’s not at all challenging to avoid them. You’ll likely only run into them if you mistime a jump and fall hard and one’s nearby, or if you kill an enemy that makes a loud noise (hazmat guy by attacking the air compressor, or have one of the bloaters blow up).- Technical issues. Even after the 1.2.1 patch, there are a few technical issues. While they obviously won’t apply to everyone, every few times I quit the game, it doesn’t exit properly. It drops me to the desktop, but the game is still running in task manager. I then have to end the task, and upon restarting the game, it begins in windowed mode, and I have to set it to full screen.Aside from the odd exit issue, cutscenes sometimes freezes for a few seconds while the audio plays. If I wind up getting hit directly by the belching zombie’s green blob thing, the game freezes for a few seconds. Lowering view distance seems to help, but I shouldn’t have to lower that to compensate for poor optimization.The Rest+ Zombie models are pretty varied, with lots of different combinations. While you will run into reused models, they’ll be few and far between.- Godlike human enemies. Zombies, sure, they might take a little to knock down. But the humans are definitely of a godlike stature. There is no reason why, after burning for ten seconds from a Molotov cocktail, that they should survive a shot to the head from a pistol, and still require a few whacks to put down for good. That’s just ridiculous.- Not much variation in the boxes or crates you run across. If you see a green, white or yellow box that looks dirty or rusty, it’ll never require a lockpick. Likewise, if you come across a box that looks nice, or adorned with something, even if it’s in the dirtiest part of the slums, it’ll require lockpicking.- Most of the side quests are typical courier fare. Go talk to person, get item for them, return, get reward. This is a good 90% of the side quests, not including the quarantine missions. It’s like an MMO in the way they’ve handled Crane being a courier.- Protected survivors. Every now and then, you’ll see a shield icon on your map; these are survivors who need escorting. They are all annoying, they don’t shut up, it’s never A to B, and they all run headfirst into every zombie without waiting for an escort. For example, a fisherman wants you to escort him to his secret fishing spot. But before that, you’ll need to escort him to his rod. And listen to him talk about what a good deal it was. There’s also the American guy. I wanted to shoot his legs out and leave him for the zombies.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Dying Light is not what I expected it to be. I wasn't really excited for the game, saw no interest in it as I am not into these zombie survival type games. However, I found a good deal on the game and thought, why the hell not? When I started playing the game I was just blown away. I wasn't expecting a beautiful open world game. I was expecting a game that tried to be as scary as possible for no reason.The story is great. It shows the epic tale of the survivors in Harran fighting to stay alive and get out of the hellhole. Once nighttime hits you realize this is the most hard and scary parts of the game. Special types of zombies appear especially at night that are ruthless killers. You can avoid the night by sleeping in your safehouses, which are located all throughout the map and you have to "liberate" to make them yours.The graphics are very gorgeous. The world is detailed and full of interesting things to explore. However, as you progress through the quests I noticed a lot of the characters looked very similar to each other and thought that ruined the immersion.The gameplay is great and frustrating at the same time. Running around Harran in the slums or old town you are constantly climbing and jumping from rooftop to rooftop. I think Techland did a great job with the parkour and nailed it. At times it felt like a first person Assassin's Creed or Mirror's Edge in a post apocalyptic world. However, the combat is sometimes very frustrating, it could take up to 10-20 hits to kill a enemy and is annoying and tedious trying to kill them.A thing Techland could have added is fast travel although it may seem like cheating in a survival game like this. It gets a little tedious and annoying running from ends of the city to the mission objectives and I feel as if there was a faster way to travel around the city it would be a lot greater. Near the end of the game we are given a grappel gun which does indeed help moving around a little faster but this is something that should be looked on in the sequel.Overall, I am happy with my purchase and I feel like the game exceeded my expectations and proves Techland can make games that don't fall into the cliche zombie survival type games.9/10

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												So here is what I have to say after a night with much less sleep than I should have got.Dying Light is going to get compaired to Techland's previous title Dead Island a lot. And it is fair that it is, because a lot of thing, big and small, feel so similar to it. However, don't let that part put you off. Really. Don't.In Dead Island, much of the combat felt like a bunch of little one on ones, with no real interaction with "the mob". In this, there seems to be so much more fluid combat to the game, send one zombie flying into about 6 others, and get the one that is still standing while the others on the floor figure out what the heck happened.While it feels like I don't have the reach I would think I do, the free running feels great. It may be quite easy to fall off a pipe you run on, at least at first. After a bit, you will have the motions down a bit more like second nature.In summary, what I am saying is this is five times better than what Dead Island was. Just... know it is a little intensive on the graphics if you want to crank it all up, espeially with mid range gaming rigs.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												A total improvement in this company's direction since Dead Island.  This one goes on the wall of rare games you will never forget and will want to play again and again (and I will definitely revisit this game often).  The story was a little weak in spots, but had a decent climactic ending in comparison to previous titles.  Story-wise, this game shines a little more with side quests, albeit some were similar to others, I didn't feel as if I was repeating mundane tasks over and over - filler-quests if you will (Just Cause 1, for ex.).  Several of the side-quests turned out to be a series of quests rather than a the snatch-and-grab-and-return-for-experience-points-and-your-done scenario.  Regardless, I can't wait to see what they do next.10/10.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												Generally I'm not a fan of zombie type games. I usually go for the fps multiplayer tactical games. However, I do enjoy a good co-op experience with friends every now and then. This game has been nothing short of impressive. They put a lot of detail into this game, not only into the world itself but the mechanics and gameplay as well. Add in a co-op player or three, and you are sure to have a blast. Roaming the world and looting can get pretty addictive, as you search for better weapons or new boosters to craft. Most of the zombies are just plain fun to kill. But,when the sun goes down, the volatiles come out and the adrenaline starts pumping as you try and outrun them trying to get to a safe zone.For most games, side missions outside of the main story line get boring and repetitive (gta 5 for example). But with dying light, I find myself more interested in just wandering around, looting, and beating up zombies, that the story is not the most important thing anymore. With that said the story here is pretty solid. And there are a tone of side missions to do as well. I've played almost 20 hours so far and am only 35% through the story!Anyways, this is a great game. If you are into zombies or looking for a fun co-op experience - pick this up!

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												I have hundreds of hours in Zombie games, from DayZ to WarZ (Or infestation survivor stories) I have played games like This War of Mine and Dead Island, this game manages to take the good aspects of these great survival and zombie games and turn them into something really special! Dying Light is a first person action, zombie, survival, parkour game, with a thirlling storyline and a loot system that reminds me of Diablo days, just not as♥♥♥♥♥♥ While the annoyance of having 'spacebar' be the singe most important key in the whole game, and when it doesn't work in a challenge or in a pinch, you are sure to die, the game for the most part is exciting! The DLC added to the game is enjoyable, I wont blow smoke up your♥♥♥♥♥ the paid DLC is obviously where it is at, some of it worth much more than the others. The Bozak hore was a challenging and rewarding experience that once I completed I felt a great sense of achievement! The other challenges in the game offer brief, but rage filled, similar experiences. I would recommend this game to a friend, it is much more enjoyable surviving the world with a friend!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												There comes a time when you simply stop being so enthusiastic about a whole bunch of games, which are being released or already are out there. You simply cannot find it exciting anymore, all those continuous franchises... fast paced, scripted gameplay, recycled stories... all bleached out and without a soul. There's a bunch, and even if you haven't experienced some of those newer combinations of elements in aforementioned types... you simply don't care. You've seen it all.But then, once in a while, comes a game which wakes up that child in you again. This is that kind of game.All the segments which make it so refreshing and enjoyable construct a unique and a special combination. Combat and player flexibility, atmosphere which is primarily enriched by the beautiful graphics - is was sets it apart. Story in this game is just a side dish. So I won't go nitpicking around, finding what's wrong with it... there is always something, saturation comes inevitably... like with almost everything in life. It is not perfect... but it is best of its kind.This is the best zombie skull smasher, while dashing through the vast city, there is... and ever was.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												I bought this game only because my friends wanted to play something coop with zombies. Let me tell you this game surprised me way more then I expected. It is so good, so well built. I fell like I'm in the movie "I Am Legend" all the time. The night is scary but the most important thing is the coop element: at first I didn't wanted to buy it cause I knew you play as a single carachter even in coop...but now I'm here to tell you that I was completely wrong. Immersion in this game is complete, the cutscenes are really good and you never feel out of the game cause of the coop. I like the melee weapons a lot, I like that you find almost no rifles and guns at the start of the game, I like the city, I like the night.The light at night...good god I love it! It is SO DARK when the moon is covered by clouds.The game is also well optimized cause the lowest settings will guarantee a GREAT graphic experience (45+ fps on a ATI 7850 i3 3220). If you like zombies games and/or first-person games with parkour and melee combat elements in it GO BUY THIS GAME!Only 1 complain: the sky texture could be better.

Posted: February 20, 2016
												Very entertaining game from what I have played. Yet to see how short the story is, but so far it has been interesting enough to keep me hopping around Haran. With the new DLC there are buggies and a whole new map to explore with friends which could be interesting to experement with. The combat is slightly boring as it becomes a case of repeatedly hitting a zombie till it lands on the ground, at which point, you hit it again. The co-op is a fun little addition, but only if your whole team knows how to play, otherwise it is a case of running back and forth to help your team. Swarms of zombies hiding on the streets can also be a big problem if you dont have Firecrackers to lure the oncoming horde away from your objective or home. Even then the radius of the firecrackers isn't all that effective.I say this game is fun but there are somethings that could be improved apon.  7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												This game is like ...gamer sex, it's awesome!!! Yes, I'm a nerd, but hey, you're here to so don't judge! Dying Light. Play it Co-Op with 1 friend you get along with, follow the side quests  do the story, it's by far the best Zombie Survival game I've played in a very long time! The graphics even on Medium are stunning, the game is fluid with very few glitches or setbacks, the learning curve is great as far as tailoring the Protagonist to how you want him to be played. Skill tree is great, crafting is entertaining. Things I don't like about the game. I'd like it to have 6 to a group rather then just 4. The in game voice quality is a bit shabby, but I use skype most days. I've been playing this everyday and I am loving every hour so far! I would recommend this to people who enjoy survival games looting crafting running for your life and fast to think of where you'll be in the next second. It's fast paced and scary! I love it. The story is very nice to listen to and the tidbits of info you get from the game is also fun to collect. The Achievements are good fun as well...I am going to complete them all.

												One of the best zombie games I've played so far, ♥♥♥♥♥ on dead island.Don't  know where to begin, game has no faults in my book.Moving around the city is awesome as the parkour aspect is easy to get used to. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												Dying Light is something of a spiritual successor to Dead Island, made by the same company and containing many of the same mechanics. You run around killing zombies, attach various junk to weapons to make them cause more and different kinds of damage, and you progress in the plot by running chores for various survivors in the city.However, this time around they've completely removed the enemy level system, making it possible to become an absolute zombie-slaying god among men once you got yourself levelled up and crafted some high-end weapons. You'll face more difficult enemies down the line for sure, and as is true to form you can get overwhelmed when too many swarm you at once, but you always have the option to level up and get more powerful stuff and come back to absolutely stomp the enemies later.They also added two new key features: Day/night cycle, and parkour. Both of which help immensly to spice up the regular zombie slaying.During the day you'll mostly only face regular zombies and the occasional special variant. You can safely run around the rooftops and outmanouver them, take them head-on with whatever blunt or sharp instrument of your choice, set up traps and blow up several at once, or just ignore them and use them as jumping blocks to reach that annoying ledge you couldnt otherwise (this move is hilarious. get it early :)During the night, however, the tone changes. The normal zombies get a little feistier, but more importantly the streets will be stalked by deadly hunter zombies called volatiles.These beasts constantly scan for anything you-shaped or you-sounding, and once they see you you better run for your life. They are NOT to be trifled with until very late in the game, and even then they're pretty dangerous. They also investigate any sound their fellow undead make, so if you take a swing at something, You better leave before they come looking.The Parkour elements provide you with the means to escape the Volatiles, as well as a fun & fast way to get around the city. You can jump and climp almost anything, giving you near total freedom of movement. Later in the game you even get a grappling hook to quickly scale even the tallest building, though it has a cooldown so you can't rely on it to save you every time when you're being persued.The story is ok. It's nothing too fancy, but it's interesting enough to keep you playing. It's definitely not the main draw of the game, but at the very least it doesn't detract from the experience.My main gripe with it comes at the end when you are suddenly forced into a QTE event which instakills you if you fail a single press. The rest of the game has only mild QTE influences, like hammering the use key to open a door, and this particular sequence come at you without warning. You'll likely die in it many times before you learn the right keypresses. The game did not need this part.All in all, the game was great fun throughout and I highly recommend it to anyone who liked the Dead Island series. Dying Light improves upon the formula in many ways, and (aside from that one-off QTE event) it all adds up to a satisfying game all the way to the end. Pros:+ Zombie killing in creative ways+ Fun parkour in an open-world city (a bit like Assassins Creed, but faster paced)+ Levelling system with abilities that heavily impacts gameplay+ You can dropkick people (great fun!)+ Crafting system from Dead Island (mostly unchanged. If it ain't broke, don't fix it?)Cons:- Not as optimized as it could be. The game has been patched to fix several issues, but you'll probably want to set draw distance to the minimum. It only reduces far away terrain detail, as far as I've seen, so you'll likely not even notice any difference.- If you want to go singleplayer-only, the game will constantly nag you about wanting to go online with no way to turn those messages off. A nitpick to be sure, but it annoyed me quite a bit.- That instakill QTE event near the end. Seriously, wtf?

												Not a Dead island Launch, the game actually works perfectly fine with no crashes and glitches. Good thing they delayed this game to prevent that from happening. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
Short and to the PointThis game was an honest shock for me as to how well it was put together. Dead Island was a special game as well but it did indeed fall short. Very buggy, awkward character development but was still enjoyable being the first Borderlands/Zombie game. Dying Light really improved on all the aspects Techland was trying to create with the original. Honestly I am happy they got away from Deep Silver. Considering the shambles that Dead Island 2 is in at the moment. The graphics have improved, animations are cleaner, characters are easier to connect with and sound design is pretty nice as well. My biggest clap is to the RPG elements of the game. All quests are mostly voiced and give you some characters to mess around with. They have a pretty good variety as well. The skill trees are pretty diverse give you some different ways to focus at first. Overall it is a great game and I totally recommend it. Awesome with friends. Things that could still use some work. Mostly story development. Although much better it still sometimes feels a little empty. In the sense as I didn't always feel the drive to get to the end all the time. Again, it wasn't bad but I still think it's one of Techlands improvement points. The animations are much better yes, but characters can also feel a bit static in the face when in conversation. I'm sure Dying Light 2 will have heavily improved face works which will immerse the emotions the game trys to convey. Also at times it seems the game doesn't always respond or connect in combat at times. It's not really bad but sometimes it just doesn't seem to work correctly. That's being very picky.One thing I would like to see in Dying Light 2 is creating your own character and gender picks. It would be a huge step for Techland but that would be awesome to have. Again, love the game, it's near perfect. Just has a few things the sequel can perfect. PLAY IT!9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												Where to start? Dying light is an open world, zombie survival, first person parkour game and I love it!Although the zombie genre is very crowded at the moment as long as your not feeling to much fatigue and you love parkour I can almost guarantee you will love this game!Pros: FANTASTIC PARKOUR SYSTEM 9/10Fast paced parkour challenges.Great graphics (Pro tip turn down view distance for almost double the amount of frames the graphical difference? Well, there isn't really one at all!)In depth skill system.Combat feels great!FOV slider ( I believe it ranges from 65* - 90* or somewhere around that)Steam workshop support.Free developer tools download to make custom maps for steam workshop.MOS SUPPORT! Last I checked (a couple days ago) mods still work! (Or the ones I tried at least I cant guarantee 100% support for every mod) the only catch is, you can only play with the people who have the same mods.Cool weapons and tools available to use.In between: PC optimization certainly isn't great, that said it isn't horrible either, you may have some problems running this on lower end rigs. I can run it 1080p texure quality: medium everything else off or low (with the exception of hbao+ depth of field etc) roughly at 30 -60 fps. Specs: Intel i7 4765t, gtx 860m factory overclocked, 16gb ddr3l.The story isn't that great, its not horrible, I would personally say its just passable from staying out of the cons category.Cons: Well... $70 USD is a little pricey, I guess thats a con, but otherwise well theres really nothing that bad about this game!The only other negative is that this is by no means an original game, it borrows very heavily of other game such as farcry 4, dead island (although they are the same people who made dying light) etc.Final verdict: 8/10 This games parkour mechanics are incredible, it is the best first person parkour simulator out there in my opinion. The combat is awesome, the skill tree mechanic implemented is well designed, I love the support for steam workshop mods and how they have giving you thye tools to make your own custom maps. I also like the regular mod support it provides (granted some wont work but there are some that do!)The story is a little tedious at times and can be a bit of a drag and the game optimization is nothing to be bragging about, and it is a little pricier than regular AAA games on the market today costing roughly $70 USD. The game also does not have an original bone in its body, but the gameplay certainly makes up for that!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I first got this game when it came out. I finished it and I enjoyed it, for the most part. I am now playing again in anticipation of the expansion coming in 2016 and I am having more fun than ever.If you enjoy survival this game is for you. Just make sure to play on Hard Mode. This is one of the very few zombie apocalypse games that made me think twice about swinging my weapon about like a kid on a temper tantrum. You will feel like a survivor in choosing tactics, evasion and mobility over brute force.Prior to Hard Mode being added, your character would much too quickly become a Johny Rambo one-man zombie killing machine, slaughtering thousands of infected without breaking a sweat. No more. Now you're just a fit guy with a bunch of saw blades duck-tapped to a brick hammer, and you know (magical) parkour. This fixes a big narrative problem with the game as it was released, captured in the following question: If its so ♥♥♥♥ing easy (for me) to slaughter my way through day and night, why in the flying ♥♥♥♥ are all these people holed up and scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? Well, Hard Mode answers that question by bringing you down a peg.Just don't come for the (main) story. Its atroucious. Side stories and characters, however, are equal parts humorous and empathetic.Get it, Play it, Enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												First of all, this game is easily the best zombie game in existence.  The parkour is phenomenal, and it complements the combat very well.  The fighting is as fun as the running, but don't expect to be a ninja at the beginning of the game.  The protagonist, Kyle Crane, hasn't much stamina, so the game has a slow start during which one needs to focus on survival; on finding enough weapons.  Durability is a huge aspect of this game.  Things break, and, once things break, they don't return.  Minecraft style.  The game doesn't take long to speed up, though.  Before you know it, your stats will be maxed out, and you'll be rolling your eyes at an inventory that's stuffed with weapons.  If the beginning is too slow for you, I find it necessary to tell you that there is a New Game Plus option.  You keep your inventory and your abilities.  Meanwhile, you enjoy the game, again.  Definitely don't worry about replayability.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												I really like this game, if you were unfortunate enough to get this when it first came out and you had a nvidia GPU you most likely would not agree with me due to all the permonace issues and game crashes etc etc. but thanks to the latest patches this game now plays flawlessly.The graphics on this game are awesome providing that your GPU can handle it but one tip i found was to set your view distance to minimum as it does not make much of a difference and you can push around another 10FPS out the game, also motion blur and film grain effect give you a few more frames if disabled.The gameplay is great; free-running whilst smashing zombies up, what not to like? A wide range of activities, chalenges, side quests, colectables and decent leveling system will keep you busy for hours. I got over 50 hours out of it but at least 10 of these hours were played after i had got everything in game. Online is rather active and you shouldnt have any issues finding groups.I definately recomend this game but make sure that your system meets the minimum requirements as quite a few people have thought that their system could run it only to be dissapointed or end up playing on much lower graphics settings.If you like Dead Island, you will like this. Think of Dead Island crossed with Mirrors edge and it should give a pretty good idea of what to expect.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Dying Light is quite a fun game, but has its downsides. Killing zombies is always fun of course. The most exciting bit is going out at night, when there are more of the bigger dangerous zombies outside. It actually is kinda scary being chased by a quick and strong zombie in the night, with almost no vision.The parkour abilities that you can use are also quite nice. However, the story is a bit dull and becomes quite boring. The game also becomes quite repetitive. Killing zombies, clearing safezones and running from one mission location to the next, is pretty much all you do.If you're looking for a game to spend a lot of time on, Dying Light is probably going to get too boring for that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												This is how a zombie survival game should be done. It makes the inevetably repetitive action of slashing/avoiding zombies fun and tactical, and the story's not too bad either. Plus, the game world is very detailed and there are lots of fun easter eggs hidden around for you to find.There are however some moments which I feel can quickly become tedious or frustrating. At later levels, fast running "viral zombies" will spawn almost constantly, and will chase you across the entire map while screaming their lungs out (and I do mean SCREAMING. The damn things don't shut up!) Additionally, I feel that night, which the game advertises as being very dangerous, is difficult for all the wrong reasons. Namely, the fact that it's exactly the same as daytime except for the addition of extremely fast zombies with a huge aggro range and an instant kill attack, which is not so much a danger as it is a massive annoyance.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												The game is a big step-up from Dead Island. The side quests aren't all generic fetch quests and the main story is actually engaging. The combat system has been reworked and the game has you feeling helpless at the start which is a very good thing. I was positively surprised by how open the map is. The only invisible walls are the boundaries of the map and story-related locations. The parkour system is also fun and pretty intuitive to use. The use of skilltrees prevents the game from going stale and adds some really big changes/additions to how you play the game.If you liked Dead Island and/or Mirror's Edge, get it.The main story quest will net you around 10h of gameplay. I have done all of the sidequests and I'm currently sitting at around 35h. The game is fun enough that I might replay it in co-op though.There have been some CPU and RAM management issues but they have all been fixed with the 1.40 Patch resulting in a dramatic increase in framerate. Props to Techland.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												7/10, good game (+1 with EE: The Following)--- edited review ---(quick review update for game version 1.11.1, Linux tested, played multiplayer The Following addon)Good news. Game finally seems to be fixed and actually is playable on 680 GTX. I assume game is not up to par with Windows version but framerates are way better than on 1.5.0.Mouse re-binding WORKS. Even SIDE BUTTONS. Hear that, 4A Games (Metro: LL)?You still have interface designed for gamepads, but doing more complex actions like selecting arrow types for the bow etc. seems to work well.Fixed: + framerates + keybindingWorth of trying, especially if you grab the enchanced edition from the Steam sales. EE includes addon campaign The Following and several minor DLC's.--- old review below ---(review for game version 1.4.0, Windows playthrough, Linux tested)edit: Linux 1.5.0 tested, low performance compared to Windows versionPlus: + generic gameplay: movement and combat is fun + woo-effect: nice looking, lots of graphical detail + gore effects: good gore effects which are not ultra-overdone Minus: - lame boss fights, QTE WTF? - exploring is not rewarding (unless for Steam achievement) - game console syndrome (awkward UI, feels like non-PC game)  - keybinding: even on Windows it's bad, and don't even mention Linux   - very low FPS on Linux/SteamOS even game is marketed as SteamOS game  - grappling hook Dying Light is Dead Island re-animated... er... zombified? Worst parts of DI have been rotten out, so you now have actually playable game.Gameplay is heavily parkour-styled, so your character, Kyle Crane, will climb and jump around the city of Harran in search of cure research for the zombie virus. Harran is made up from two large areas Slums and Old Town, which are enough distinct to spark your EXPLORE!-fire again when you change the map. The game world is quite amazing and graphics developers have been doing marvelous job to add lots of details all around. Exploring the world will give you XP, but when you hit the level cap the rewards from exploring won't account much unless you play for Steam achievements. On the other hand, as there aren't any practical reason to explore more, two large map areas will suffice.Movement is fluid and usually you get intended action (grab a ledge, jump off from the wall) so you actually feel like you're doing parkour moves. If surface looks like it could be grapped or climbed, that's usually the case. Movement skill level also adds to the feeling that Kyle Crane physically learns more as he goes on. Having seen some games which kind of sucked (Mirror World *cough* *cough*) and some games where all surfaces are fair game (Ninja Gaiden), doing parkour in DL is simply fun. Of course some movement restrictions are in place as game world is finite, there are surfaces you can't grab and gameplay area is confined by magical invisible walls. Later on you get grappling hook, while it speeds up gameplay considerably, you lose most of the illusion of being parkour runner.Combat system is fairly simple. Neverthless it's entertaining enough for few hours just to bash, slash, maul and maim zombies with whatever weapon you get on your hands. Zombies react to physics, so they can tackled, toppled over fences or forced to climb on high places to even reach you (and then they get kick in the face). You're able to target generic body area so usually button mashing is a great combat tactic. There is unfortunate auto-targetting when doing some combat moves but I guess it's price to pay for playing console game. Story is kind of mixed bag, as side quests have more story than the main quest. Most of NPCs have at least somewhat interesting dialogue and voice acting & animations are ok, some overacting, but also some really excellent performances. Most of the default story line aspects living in the city full of undead are handled in way or another through side quests or collectibles. Unfortunately main quest includes some really dumb forced story events, bad boss seems to have constant grip from Crane's balls whatever Kyle tries to do. Kyle Crane voice acting shows him as quite strong-willed character, he's not on par with JC Denton but delivers his punch lines with real punch well enough (except every time when Kyle meets evil boss he puts whimp clothes on so he can receive good spanking). I have kind of insight after my playthrough that Techland can't make a game without horrible main story twists. Dead Island was such a dog puke, DL is bit better though as side quests will give some credibility for the story writer.Of course the zombie game aren't zombie game at all if there aren't any gibs! In DL zombie gibs are also finite, for example you can't cut only fingers off, then palm off, wrist off and so on, you only chop off whole hand from elbow. Gore effects are fairly well done and stay within reasonable limits so you can enjoy the effects and do not get WTFs every time. Gore with taste, I say! Also splatter effects on walls seems to correspond with weapon you're using.User Interface is designed for consoles, game has "hold this key and move mouse"-style weapon/item menu. This might work if you have gamepad or such, but I played this with keyboard and mouse. You can rebind the keys, but you need to limit yourself to only some items or juggle through awkward inventory if you want to use more items (especially elixirs). Also keybinding on Linux version is horrible and mouse recognizes only 3 buttons.Of course review would not be completed without nitpicking about some things. Developers are marketing this game for Linux/SteamOS and then when you buy it you will experience about half of  FPS of what it should achieve. DON'T BUY THIS GAME FOR LINUX/STEAMOS until developers fix this! Patch 1.5 recently came out and fixed some issues. I tested Linux version with same hardware and fact is game does not perform well enough to be playable.Also final battle with the boss is just one facepalm moment you can't forget. So, you're ready with best weapons with best upgrades, holding boss' own gun to give it back one bullet at time and lots of invulnerability elixirs to gulp. You climb on the final ledge ready to pump this guy full of lead and then chop him to tiny grilled evil zombi-snack bits with your Fiery Sword of Death. Well, that's how it should go? Instead you're treated with Quick-Time Event (QTE) where one-handed man beats your zombi-killing hero to ground only using one hand and whole battle...  no, not battle... watching interactive movie... consist of pressing seven buttons in certain order. WTF? In fact, here's pro-tip for you: in this game you can discard your weapons before playing any main quests against boss as you can't never use them.Conclusion: despite some shortcomings this is quite fun game. Main story sucks but as one NPC said to Crane, blockbuster movies are all about happy endings and badly told stories. Here's story for 70€ (incl. Season Pass). As long you remember to turn your brain off for the main story quest, you should have fun. Worst letdowns are technical problems with SteamOS/Linux version (hopefully to be patched) and main story had lots of brain-dead parts in it.On the bright side, gameplay is fun and entertaining for one playthrough. Multiplayer might add some more hours, but I'll suggest you first try the game on single player or with newbie friends as best parts of the game experience is at the beginning of the game. I would say with more experienced story designer, ironing out all technical problems before release and adapting interface more for keyboard/mouse this could have been excellent gem. Anyways, it's worth of try if you buy game for Windows. I can't recommend buying this game for Linux/SteamOS and paying full price.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												I have to admit, I was a bit skeptical about this game. I'm not (or better, I wasn't) a big fan of parkour-style games, but Dying Light proved to be a great buy. If you like running, jumping, falling, bashing zombies, running away from zombies, really running from scary freaks when night falls and eventually finding some guns and weapon upgrades so you can do some serious damage while you run and jump, then this is your game. Parkour, many side quests to keep you busy, great soundtrack, upgradeable skills, upgradeable weapons that can really smash zombies (including an electrified cricket bat, respect to the developers), all manner of potions, some creative traps and more running and jumping. You also have a lot of freedom in how you go about doing things, so you can take your time and brain some infected while you hone your jumping/crashing-to-the-ground skills.Graphically very good, control-responsive, no glitches or bugs to report. Awesome game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Dying Light... spiritual successor to Dead IslandWhy spiritual successor? Deep Silver acquired the rights of the Dead Island franchise and Yager is developing Dead Island 2. Dying Light is made by Techland and is a completely new franchise however, very much inspired of Dead Island 1 and Riptide!Okay, now finished with the story mode. Here is the updated review!For gamers on the fence with this game, I can honestly tell you that it is a fun game. Granted, I liked Dead Island 1 even with the repetitiveness, bad voice acting and goofy humor but Dying Light has many differences. It's got a more serious tone and the setting is mainly focused on survival. You finally have a day/night cycle and lemme give you an idea how's the night cycle... Exactly like the movie I AM LEGEND. You run for your life if you dare do stuff at night... You can try to kill one of those "Volatiles" but highly not recommended until you are high level, like at least 10 or you'll just get killed easily by them swarming you. Thing is, just like I AM LEGEND, once a Volatile spots you, it screams and then you get swarmed by other Volatiles and Virals. So, better do exactly like Will Smith and run like hell!A good change from Dead Island is you do not level up once for many ability trees but once for every three and just by playing. If you do lots of parkour, you level faster in the Agility tree... if you lockpick many chests, you level up faster the survivor tree, etc. I think this is a cool new system and a welcome change from Dead Island where you had many trees of abilities and had to focus on specific trees as well.As for the story, it is about you, the character, that gets airdropped to Harran, the quarantined city that has a nasty epidemic going on. You are sent to investigate while blending in with the locals, who are fighting each other for the sparse resources scattered over the city. Brief synopsis but better than Dead Island. It drags on for long though which I was a tad disappointed but it gets the job done!PROS:+A very stable game especially at launch! The delay did paid off it seems!+Outstanding visuals (graphics, models, weather effects, animations, etc).+Old school style soundtrack!+Decent voice acting unlike cheesy Dead Island!+Fantastic "old-school style" soundtrack. Really gives that '80s zombie vibe!+Fun First Person Parkour done right (mostly!).+Rewarding carnage that never gets old!+Three-way levelling up is an innovative way to keep you playing.+Highly tensed Night cycle.+Lots of lots of exploration with many side quests. Basically, lots of contents to keep you busy for many hours!+Co-op and competitive play (Be the Zombie) can add up replayability but as of now, the Zombie mode lacks balance.+Many easter eggs! I haven't seen many in-game but I watched a few Youtbue videos and Techland went nuts with those eggs!CONS:-Underwhelming story with an ambiguous ending leading to story DLC (highly likely).-Tedious side-quests. Get to point A then to B and backtracks to A and then go to C to the otherside of the whole map. -No fast travel until you beat the campaign that is.-Last level parkour running is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Be prepared to do many retries!-QTE last boss fight.-Unbalanced competitive Zombie mode. Just spam UV light and the Volatile/Zombie is toast!-Lackluster season pass content (it includes two missions for dlc1 then items pack for dlc2 and some horde mode for dlc3). I'd advise anyone to wait for it since the content doesn't seem worth the purchase right now.OVERALL:If you loved Dead Island, you should love this one as it is much better in every ways. Its not cheesy like DI and more survival focused. The game is not perfect (heck, has any game ever been?), has a few faults here and there but the goods outweight the cons and I had lots of decent fun in this sweet violent game.On the technical side, the game was quite stable on my rig with every settings maxed out. I only had one crash to desktop but it may have been on my fault since I didn't restarted the game once I upped the settings. Aside from that, the game runs A-OK to me! The delay this game got surely went into QA and I wish more games would do the same. To see a new modern AA/AAA game releasing on DAY ONE and working properly is exceptionnal nowadays!RECOMMENDATION:I recommend this game especially if you loved Dead Island, you will truly love Dying Light. Many improvements to be seen/experienced. Is it worth the retail price? YES! Especially if you're looking into a new game right now, then give it a shot!RATING:8.0 / 10THE FOLLOWING DLCThe Following DLC picks up exactly where you left of. You are meeting a character that tells you of a cure to the devastating plague in Harran from a friend but his dying words mentions to travel in a new location. Once there, you get to play around and even drive a dune buggy (that you can improve as you level up the Driver section). There is new enemies that you find who are labelled as "elite enemies" that you "shouldn't fight on your own"... which is correct if you play the game in Nightmare mode! Talking difficulty level, I played the whole DL game in nightmare mode and it was mostly fair fights! But in TF, nightmare mode is a bigger chore. Enemies have more hit points and your damages are very low. You also die more easily vs Volatiles at night... or in Volatiles Nests! The Countryside region is BIG and fun to explore but my biggest gripe with Dying Light is you don't have ANY fast travel... and almost all quests/missions are all far apart, implying lots of driving and time spent there.SPOILER ALERTEnding is... bad. I liked it! Basically, you have two choices... sacrifice yourself and all those pointless quests, for the greater good by activating a nuke OR, fight The Mother (Sentient Volatile that can walk in day light but turns mindless killer at night) and "save your friends"... by infecting them with your "Volatile cure"! Both endings, I find cool! Would be interesting to keep the story going with your Volatile self and for the mission, infect a whole city! Would be a cool new game style!.PROS:+Massive new area to drive through and explore.+Frantic gameplay in Volatile hives!+Dune buggy is a fun new gameplay mechanic+Interesting cult conspiracy story.CONS:-More fetch quest missions (the annoying part is from far away locations).-Boring and stupid protagonist Kyle Crane (your character).-The fast respawns of zombies in cleared zones is very irritating.RATING:8.0 / 10

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												Wow! One of the best games I have ever played. I love zombie themed games and this is basically FarCry 3 with Zombies (seriously I'm convinced the devs from Dying Light used the same engine as there were features that I've absolutely seen in both games). An absolute must play. 10/10Pros- Story and cutscene animations are excellent- Gorgeous (or should I say disgusting?) artwork really helps with the vibe- The Parkour is some of the most fun part of the game- Weapons are fantastic - RPG elements unlock new features at a good pace- Game world is huge with lots of in-game content that will let you keep playing long after the main storyline is over- The night missions help you never feel quite safe even when your character is overpowered- The Following episode adds the buggy. Running over zombies is more fun than I would like to admit.- The game is not overly frightening but the engine can randomly produce some decent jump scaresCons- The later The Following episode had a number of "soft" ledges where the character would miss grabbing on to something that the skin made look grabbable. This led to quite a few annoying deaths during high climbs. - The Bozak's horde extra missions had a great idea but the save system annoyed me to the point that I decided not to finish them.- Eventually your character becomes so overpowered that killing zombies can become almost a nuisance- Besides adding missions, once a safe zone is unlocked it didn't have much more to offer than a safe place to sleep and/or sell stuff. I felt this was a missed opportunity as I would have loved to see some base building or defense elements included in the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Countless hours of fun! After some time is put into character development the fun meter just keeps rising. Are you a slaughter monster? This game caters to you. Very satisfying zombie bashing combat abilities that are devastating and gory. You more the scout type, play it realistic? There is room for you in Dying Light as well! This game has something I really like, a majority of the enemies are CLASSIC zombies! The move like you would expect and only special types can book it after you. Even before you unlock the plethora of wickid Parkour (Agility) abilities you are able to move around, over, and through the swarms of deadies with relative ease. It is really really enjoyable to run through crowds of shambling zombies, turning and sidestepping like a dance as zeds reach for you and miss as you cut through the crowd like butter. And as even better feeling is reaching your hands into a freshly killed zombie and smear their guts all over your face and body and just moving WITH the hordes. Anyway you look at it there is something for every zombie fan, as well as most action/adventure fans as well! PLENTY of thrilling moments backed up with a solid and cool storyline. Tons of weapons and collectibles. Great crafting system. Well balanced levelling system. And many many side quests. Not to mention playing with even ONE friend in cooperative mode completely changes the game. Going out in groups is almost cathartic! You basically feel like you can handle anything slow and steady whether you are luring enemies, setting traps, or just aiming high with sweet melee weapons from flanking positions, attacks from both sides, or just classic kick*** back to back slaughterfest. I personally suggest everyone try modding a sledgehammer for impact and watch as your dead foes go sailing out of the park! Basically, there are many many ways to play and enjoy the aspects of this game from the movement (my favorite part) to the fighting, to the moral dilemmas. A real treat for anyone who it runs smoothly for. I was lucky to not have been affected by a lot of the initial bugs and optimization.
